page.title: 01Somerford Keynes, Glos.
page.content: This is flattish countryside of the Upper Thames Valley with the infant River Thames flowing through it. The landscape is primarily a productive agricultural land growing grain, rape, grass for hay and silage with grazing land for sheep and cattle. The people who farm the land live in the villages and hamlets of the block. The shallow topsoil in the southern part overlies sand and gravel which is being extracted on a large scale, forming gravel pits whose after use for sailing, fishing etc forms part of the Cotswold Water Park. Someford Keynes, first was mentioned in a Saxon Charter of 685 and also recorded in the original Domesday Book, celebrated its 1300th anniversary in 1985. The population is about 350, having grown quickly in the last decade. The recent residents work mainly in
